case_name: Indore Iron and Steel Registered Stock-holders Association Private Ltd. v. State of Madhya Bharat

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 509 and 510 of 1960 were filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 509 and 510 of 1960. Appeals by special leave

facts.text: Appeals by special leave from judgment and order dated October 26, 1956 of Madhya Bharat High Court Indore in Civil Misc. Cases Nos. 26 of 54 and 48 of 55.

anchor.surface_text: from the judgment and order dated October 26, 1956, of the former Madhya Bharat High Court Indore. in Civil Misc. Cases Nos. 26 of 54 and 48 of 55.

facts.text: Appellant is Indore Iron and Steel Registered Stock-holders Association Private Ltd., a registered association.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.,The appellant, the Indore Iron and Steel Registered Stock-holders Association  Private  Ltd., is a registered Association

facts.text: Constituent members of appellant carry on business in fabricated iron and steel material including iron sheets, bars, rods, structurals, nails, wire, pipes at Indore and Ratlam.

anchor.surface_text: whose companystituent members carry on business generally in fabricated iron and steel material and more particularly in iron sheets, plain or companyrugated, bars, rods, light and heavy structurals, nails, joints, wire nails and all kinds and varieties of wirer, and pipes.

facts.text: State of Madhya Bharat by Act No. 30 of 1950 imposed sales tax on sales of specified goods effective from May 1, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: This business is carried on by the companystituent members of the appellant at Indore and Ratlam at which places they have their registered offices. The State of Madhya Bharat, by its Act No. 30 of 1950, imposed sales tax

facts.text: Commissioner of Sales Tax, Madhya Bharat (respondent 2) and Sales Tax Officer, Indore (respondent 3) appointed for assessment and recovery of tax.

anchor.surface_text: in the territory of Madhya Bharat on the sales of goods therein specified with effect from May 1, 1950, and under the provisions of the said Act the Commissioner of Sales Tax, Madhya Bharat, and the, Sales Tax Officer, Indore, who are respondents 2 and 3,

facts.text: Notification issued on May 22, 1950 under s.5(2) specifying articles taxed including item 27: goods manufactured from metals except gold and silver etc., tax at Rs. 3-2-0 per cent by producer or importer.

anchor.surface_text: On May 22, 1950. a numberification was issued under s. 5 2  specifying serially the articles taxed, the stage of sale by traders in Madhya Bharat on which the tax is levied and the rate of sales tax per cent Item 27 in the list dealt with goods manu- factured from things  wastu  except gold and silver or goods manufactured from more than one metal  except circles and sheets of companyper, brass and aluminium .

facts.text: Article 286(3) of the Constitution came into force before the parliamentary declaration.

anchor.surface_text: The numberifications provided that the tax had to be paid by the producer or importer at that rate of Rs. 3-2-0 per cent. Meanwhile Art. 286 3  of the Constitution had companye into force.

facts.text: Parliament passed Act 52 of 1952 on August 9, 1952, declaring iron and steel (Sch. item 14) essential for life of community under s.2.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter Parliament by law proceeded to make the declaration as companytemplated by this Article by s. 2 of Act 52 of 1952 Essential Goods  Declaration and Regulation of Tax on sale or purchase  Act  hereafter called the Act  which was passed on August 9, 1952.

facts.text: State issued two notifications on October 24, 1953: first no tax on sale of iron and steel (item 39); second tax on every kind of metal excluding iron, steel, gold, silver and goods prepared from metals etc. (item 9).

anchor.surface_text: Respondent 1 thereupon purported to give effect to the provisions of Art. 286 3  and s. 2 of the Act by issuing two numberifications on October 24, 1953. By the first numberification it was provided that numbertax shall be payable enter alia on the sale of iron and steel.

facts.text: It is common ground that under the October 24, 1953 notification, articles dealt by appellant's constituents are liable to sales tax.

anchor.surface_text: Iron and steel was placed at item 39 in the said Schedule. The other numberification issued on the same day by item 9 in the list provided for the sale of the articles specified in the said item. ... It is companymon-ground that under this numberification the articles

facts.text: Appellant wrote to respondent 3 claiming exemption from sales tax, plea rejected, constituents called to pay tax on individual turnover.

anchor.surface_text: in which the companystituents of the appellant deal would be liable to pay the sales. tax in question. After this numberification was issued the appellant wrote to respondent 3 claiming exemption from payment of sales tax for the goods and articles

facts.text: Appellant filed two writ petitions under Art. 226 in High Court of Madhya Bharat at Indore: Nos. 26 of 1954 and 48 of 1955 challenging assessment orders for 1953-54 and 1954-55.

anchor.surface_text: but this plea was rejected by the said respondent, and the companystituent members of the appellant were called upon to pay sales tax each in respect of their individual turnover. It was under these circumstances that the appellant filed two writ petitions under Art. 226

facts.text: High Court dismissed the writ petitions, upholding respondents' plea that notification valid.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has upheld the plea raised by the respondents, rejected the companytentions urged by the appellant and has dismissed the writ petitions filed by it.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeals Nos. 509 and 510 of 1960 brought by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: It is against these orders of dismissal passed by the High Court in the two writ petitions filed by the appellant that the present appeals, No. 509 and 510 of 1960, have been brought to this Court by special leave granted by this Court.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Gajendragadkar J. on July 26, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: V. Viswanatha Sastri, C. B. Agarwala and A. G. Ratna parkhi, for the appellants. J. Bhave and 1. N. Shroff, for the respon. dents. 1961. July 26. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.,

facts.text: Petitioner contended that s.2 of Act 52/1952 covers iron and steel in commercial sense including fabricated articles made exclusively from iron and steel.

anchor.surface_text: Two points have been urged before us by Mr. Viswanatha Sastri, on behalf of the appellant, in support of these appeals. It is urged that s. 2 of the Act which companytains the parliamentary declaration as companytemplated by Art. 286 3  companyers iron and steel

facts.text: High Court held that iron and steel in Entry 14 Sch. of Act do not include articles made of iron and steel.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court Was number impressed by this argument. It has held that the words iron and steel as used in Entry 14 to Sch. 1 of the Act do number include within their ambit articles made of iron and steel

facts.text: Supreme Court assumed arguendo that parliamentary declaration covers appellant's commodities but held impugned notification does not contravene Art. 286(3) because Act 30 of 1950 predates declaration.

anchor.surface_text: Since we have reached the companyclusion that even on the assumption that the parliamentary declaration made by the relevant provision of the Act includes companymodities with which we are companycerned is companyrect it does number follow that the impugned numberification companytravened Art. 286 3

facts.text: Act 30 of 1950 passed after Constitution, satisfies first condition of Art. 286(3), but not second as no pre-existing parliamentary declaration.

anchor.surface_text: This companydition is satisfied in the present case because the impugned numberification has been issued by virtue of the authority delegated to respondent 1 by Act 30 of 1950 and this Act was passed after the Constitution was adopted.

facts.text: s.3 of Act 52/1952 applies prospectively to laws made after its commencement.

anchor.surface_text: It provides that numberlaw made after the companymencement of this Act by Legislature of a State imposing or authorising the imposition of t tax on the sale or purchase of any goods declared by this Act

facts.text: Impugned notification issued under Act 30 of 1950 is outside purview of s.3 of Act 52/1952.

anchor.surface_text: The impugned numberification with which we are companycerned and the Act under which it has been issued are thus outside the purview of s. 3 of the Act.

facts.text: High Court conclusion on this point is correct.

anchor.surface_text: That in substance is the finding made by the High Court on the second companytention raised before it by the appellant. In our opinion, the companyclusion of the High Court on t is point is right.

issues.text: whether the words iron and steel in respect of which the requisite parliamentary declaration has been made by s. 2 of the Act include commodities like those with which we are concerned

anchor.surface_text: It is clear that even if we were to accept Mr. Sastris contention in regard to the denotation of the words ,iron and steel as used by the relevant provisions of the Act it would still have to be shown by the appellant that the impugned notification is invalid because it contravenes the provisions of Art. 286 3 . In other words, in order to succeed in the present appeals the appellant has to prove two facts,  1  that the words iron and steel in respect of which the requisite parliamentary declaration has been made by s. 2 of the Act include commodities like those with which we are concerned

issues.text: whether the impugned notification contravenes Art. 286 3

anchor.surface_text: , and  2  that the impugned notification contravenes Art. 286 3 . It would thus be seen that unless the appellant succeeds in both these contentions the appeals are bound to fail. Since we have reached the conclusion that even on the assumption that the parliamentary declaration made by the relevant provision of the Act includes commodities with which we are concerned is correct it does not follow that the impugned notification contravened Art. 286 3  we do not propose to deal with the first point raised by Mr. Sastri.

issues.text: whether Art. 286(3) can be successfully invoked only if three conditions are satisfied

anchor.surface_text: That takes us to the provisions of Art. 286 3  which we have already cited. This provision can be successfully invoked only if three conditions are satisfied. The first condition is that the impugned law must be one which is made by the Legislature of a State which obviously means a State which came into existence under and after the Constitution and that shows that the impugned law must be a law made by the Legislature of a State subsequent to the Constitution. This condition is satisfied in the present case because the impugned notification has been issued by virtue of the authority delegated to respondent 1 by Act 30 of 1950 and this Act was passed after the Constitution was adopted.

holdings.text: Even assuming arguendo that the parliamentary declaration under s.2 of Act 52 of 1952 includes the commodities dealt in by the appellant's constituents, it does not follow that the impugned notification contravenes Art. 286(3)

anchor.surface_text: Since we have reached the conclusion that even on the assumption that the parliamentary declaration made by the relevant provision of the Act includes commodities with which we are concerned is correct it does number follow that the impugned numberification companytravened Art. 286 3

holdings.reasoning_summary: Not all three conditions precedent for invoking Art. 286(3) are met, particularly the requirement of a pre-existing parliamentary declaration

holdings.text: Art. 286(3) can be successfully invoked only if three conditions are satisfied: (1) the law is made by a State Legislature after the Constitution; (2) it imposes tax on goods already declared essential by Parliament; (3) it has been reserved for the President's consideration and assent

anchor.surface_text: That takes us to the provisions of Art. 286 3 which we have already cited. This provision can be successfully invoked only if three conditions are satisfied. The first condition is that the impugned law must be one which is made by the Legislature of a State which obviously means a State which came into existence under and after the Constitution and that shows that the impugned law must be a law made by the Legislature of a State subsequent to the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis of the language of Art. 286(3) requiring pre-existing declaration and post-Constitution law with Presidential assent mechanism

holdings.text: The first condition under Art. 286(3) is satisfied as the impugned notification was issued under Act 30 of 1950 passed after the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: This condition is satisfied in the present case because the impugned notification has been issued by virtue of the authority delegated to respondent 1 by Act 30 of 1950 and this Act was passed after the Constitution was adopted.

holdings.text: The second condition under Art. 286(3) is not satisfied because it requires a pre-existing parliamentary declaration of essentiality at the time the state law is passed; subsequent declaration has no retrospective effect

anchor.surface_text: Let us then consider the second condition which is also in the nature of a condition precedent. This condition requires that the impugned law must impose or authorise the imposition of a tax on the sale or purchase of any such goods as have been declared by Parliament by law to be essential for the life of the community. There can be little doubt that this condition postulates that at the time when the impugned law is passed there is a preexisting declaration made by Parliament in regard to the essential character of a commodity.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Parliamentary declaration post-dates Act 30 of 1950; Art. 286(3) contemplates existing declaration before state law

holdings.text: Section 3 of Act 52 of 1952 operates prospectively and applies only to state laws made after its commencement

anchor.surface_text: It provides that no law made after the commencement of this Act by Legislature of a State imposing or authorising the imposition of t tax on the sale or purchase of any goods declared by this Act

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit textual language 'no law made after the commencement of this Act'

holdings.text: The impugned notification issued under Act 30 of 1950 is outside the purview of s.3 of Act 52 of 1952

anchor.surface_text: The impugned notification with which we are concerned and the Act under which it has been issued are thus outside the purview of s. 3 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Act 30 of 1950 and notification pre-date commencement of Act 52 of 1952; s.3 prospective

holdings.text: The conclusion of the High Court that the impugned notification is valid is correct
holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court correctly applied Art. 286(3) and s.3 Act 52/1952; affirmed by analysis and precedents

anchor.surface_text: That takes us to the provisions of Art. 286 3 which we have already cited. This provision can be successfully invoked only if three conditions are satisfied. The first condition is that the impugned law must be one which is made by the Legislature of a State which obviously means a State which came into existence under and after the Constitution and that shows that the impugned law must be a law made by the Legislature of a State subsequent to the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Let us then consider the second condition which is also in the nature of a condition precedent. This condition requires that the impugned law must impose or authorise the imposition of a tax on the sale or purchase of any such goods as have been declared by Parliament by law to be essential for the life of the community. There can be little doubt that this condition postulates that at the time when the impugned law is passed there is a preexisting declaration made by Parliament in regard to the essential character of a commodity.
